cards.front: A call option gives the buyer the right to do what?
cards.back: Buy the underlying stock at the strike price

cards.front: A put option gives the buyer the right to do what?
cards.back: Sell the underlying stock at the strike price

cards.front: What is the obligation of a call option writer (seller)?
cards.back: To sell the stock at the strike price if the buyer exercises

cards.front: What is the obligation of a put option writer (seller)?
cards.back: To buy the stock at the strike price if the buyer exercises

cards.front: An investor who is BULLISH on a stock would buy what type of option?
cards.back: A call option (right to buy at a fixed price as price rises)

cards.front: An investor who is BEARISH on a stock would buy what type of option?
cards.back: A put option (right to sell at a fixed price as price falls)

cards.front: A call option is in-the-money when the market price is _____ the strike price.
cards.back: ABOVE (Call up = in the money when price goes UP above strike)

cards.front: A put option is in-the-money when the market price is _____ the strike price.
cards.back: BELOW (Put down = in the money when price goes DOWN below strike)

cards.front: What is the premium of an option?
cards.back: The price paid by the buyer to the seller for the option contract

cards.front: How many shares does one standard equity option contract represent?
cards.back: 100 shares

cards.front: What is a covered call?
cards.back: Selling a call option while owning the underlying stock (limits risk)

cards.front: What is an uncovered (naked) call?
cards.back: Selling a call option without owning the underlying stock (unlimited risk)

cards.front: When interest rates rise, what happens to bond prices?
cards.back: Bond prices FALL (inverse relationship)

cards.front: When interest rates fall, what happens to bond prices?
cards.back: Bond prices RISE (inverse relationship)

cards.front: What is nominal yield (coupon rate)?
cards.back: The fixed annual interest rate stated on the bond at issuance (never changes)

cards.front: How do you calculate current yield?
cards.back: Annual interest payment รท Current market price

cards.front: A bond trading at 102 is trading at a _____.
cards.back: PREMIUM (above par value of 100)

cards.front: A bond trading at 97 is trading at a _____.
cards.back: DISCOUNT (below par value of 100)

cards.front: For a DISCOUNT bond, which yield is highest: Nominal, Current, or YTM?
cards.back: YTM is highest. Order: YTM > Current Yield > Nominal Yield

cards.front: For a PREMIUM bond, which yield is highest: Nominal, Current, or YTM?
cards.back: Nominal is highest. Order: Nominal > Current Yield > YTM

cards.front: What is Yield to Maturity (YTM)?
cards.back: The total return earned if the bond is held until maturity, accounting for purchase price, coupon, and time

cards.front: What is interest rate risk?
cards.back: The risk that rising interest rates will cause bond prices to fall

cards.front: What is the primary tax benefit of municipal bonds?
cards.back: Interest income is exempt from federal income tax

cards.front: What backs a General Obligation (GO) bond?
cards.back: The full faith, credit, and taxing power of the issuing municipality

cards.front: What backs a revenue bond?
cards.back: Revenue from a specific project (toll roads, hospitals, airports, etc.)

cards.front: Which is generally safer: GO bonds or revenue bonds?
cards.back: GO bonds (backed by taxing power vs. project revenue)

cards.front: What does 'triple tax exempt' mean for municipal bonds?
cards.back: Exempt from federal, state, AND local taxes (for in-state residents)

cards.front: Which investors benefit MOST from municipal bonds?
cards.back: Investors in high tax brackets (the tax savings are more valuable)

cards.front: What is an official statement?
cards.back: The disclosure document for municipal bonds (equivalent to a prospectus)

cards.front: What does a bond counsel's 'unqualified opinion' mean?
cards.back: No legal problems found with the bond issue (what issuers want)

cards.front: What is an open-end fund (mutual fund)?
cards.back: A fund that continuously issues and redeems shares at NAV

cards.front: What is a closed-end fund?
cards.back: A fund with a fixed number of shares that trade on an exchange at market price

cards.front: How do you calculate NAV (Net Asset Value)?
cards.back: (Total Assets - Total Liabilities) รท Shares Outstanding

cards.front: What is forward pricing for mutual funds?
cards.back: Orders are executed at the next calculated NAV (typically 4:00 PM ET)

cards.front: What is the maximum sales charge allowed for mutual funds?
cards.back: 8.5% of the public offering price (POP)

cards.front: What is the 75-5-10 diversification rule?
cards.back: 75% in securities, max 5% in any one issuer, max 10% of any issuer's voting stock

cards.front: What is a 12b-1 fee?
cards.back: An annual marketing/distribution fee charged by mutual funds (max 1% of assets)

cards.front: What is a breakpoint in mutual fund investing?
cards.back: A dollar amount at which the sales charge is reduced for larger investments

cards.front: How do ETFs differ from mutual funds in trading?
cards.back: ETFs trade throughout the day on exchanges; mutual funds trade once daily at NAV

cards.front: What is an ETN (Exchange-Traded Note)?
cards.back: An unsecured debt security that tracks an index (has issuer credit risk, unlike ETFs)

cards.front: What defines a money market instrument?
cards.back: Short-term debt (maturity of 1 year or less), high liquidity, low risk

cards.front: What is commercial paper?
cards.back: Short-term unsecured promissory notes issued by corporations (max 270 days)

cards.front: What is a banker's acceptance?
cards.back: A bank-guaranteed instrument used for international trade financing

cards.front: What does SLoBS stand for and what does it tell you?
cards.back: Sell Limit or Buy Stop - these orders are placed ABOVE the current market price

cards.front: What does BLiSS stand for and what does it tell you?
cards.back: Buy Limit or Sell Stop - these orders are placed BELOW the current market price

cards.front: What is a market order?
cards.back: An order to buy or sell immediately at the best available price (execution guaranteed, price not)

cards.front: What is a limit order?
cards.back: An order to buy or sell at a specific price or better (price guaranteed, execution not)

cards.front: What is a stop order (stop-loss)?
cards.back: An order that becomes a market order once a trigger price is reached

cards.front: What is a stop-limit order?
cards.back: An order that becomes a limit order (not market) once trigger price is reached

cards.front: What is a day order?
cards.back: An order that expires at the end of the trading day if not executed

cards.front: What is a GTC (Good 'Til Canceled) order?
cards.back: An order that remains active until executed or canceled by the investor

cards.front: What is front running?
cards.back: Trading ahead of a large customer order to profit from the anticipated price movement

cards.front: What is churning?
cards.back: Excessive trading in a customer's account to generate commissions

cards.front: What is pump and dump?
cards.back: Artificially inflating a stock's price through false statements, then selling for profit

cards.front: What is insider trading?
cards.back: Trading based on material, non-public information about a company

cards.front: What is marking the close?
cards.back: Placing trades at or near market close to manipulate the closing price

cards.front: What is backing away?
cards.back: A market maker refusing to honor their quoted bid or ask price

cards.front: What is free-riding?
cards.back: Buying securities and selling them before paying for the initial purchase

cards.front: What is a breakpoint sale violation?
cards.back: Selling just below a breakpoint to avoid giving the customer a discount on sales charges

cards.front: What is selling dividends?
cards.back: Encouraging customers to buy a fund right before ex-dividend date (creates unnecessary tax liability)

cards.front: What is interpositioning?
cards.back: Adding unnecessary middlemen to a transaction, increasing costs to the customer

cards.front: What is a cash account?
cards.back: An account where the customer pays in full for all securities purchased

cards.front: What is a margin account?
cards.back: An account where the customer can borrow money from the broker to buy securities

cards.front: Under Regulation T, what is the initial margin requirement?
cards.back: 50% of the purchase price must be deposited by the customer

cards.front: What is a UTMA/UGMA account?
cards.back: A custodial account for a minor where an adult custodian manages assets until the minor reaches majority

cards.front: Can UTMA/UGMA accounts trade on margin?
cards.back: NO - custodial accounts cannot use margin

cards.front: Can IRA accounts trade on margin?
cards.back: NO - retirement accounts cannot use margin

cards.front: What is the difference between JTWROS and TIC accounts?
cards.back: JTWROS: deceased owner's share goes to survivor. TIC: deceased owner's share goes to estate

cards.front: What is discretionary authority?
cards.back: Written authorization allowing a representative to make trades without prior customer approval

cards.front: What is regular way settlement for stocks and bonds?
cards.back: T+1 (trade date plus one business day)

cards.front: What is cash settlement?
cards.back: Same-day settlement (must be requested before 2:30 PM)

cards.front: What happens on the ex-dividend date?
cards.back: The stock trades without the dividend; buyers on or after this date don't receive the dividend

cards.front: What is the role of the NSCC?
cards.back: National Securities Clearing Corporation - clears and settles trades between broker-dealers

cards.front: What is the Know Your Customer (KYC) rule?
cards.back: FINRA Rule 2090 requiring firms to know and verify essential customer facts when opening accounts

cards.front: What factors must be considered for suitability (FINRA Rule 2111)?
cards.back: Age, financial situation, tax status, investment objectives, time horizon, risk tolerance, liquidity needs

cards.front: What is the primary market?
cards.back: Where new securities are issued and sold for the first time (IPOs, new bond issues)

cards.front: What is the secondary market?
cards.back: Where previously issued securities are traded between investors

cards.front: What is the first market?
cards.back: Trading on regulated exchanges (NYSE, Nasdaq)

cards.front: What is the second market?
cards.back: OTC trading of unlisted securities

cards.front: What is the third market?
cards.back: Exchange-listed securities traded OTC (off-exchange)

cards.front: What is the fourth market?
cards.back: Direct institution-to-institution trading without brokers (dark pools)

cards.front: How does NYSE differ from Nasdaq in market structure?
cards.back: NYSE: auction market with one DMM per stock. Nasdaq: dealer/negotiated market with multiple market makers

cards.front: What is a DMM (Designated Market Maker)?
cards.back: A specialist on NYSE who maintains fair and orderly markets in assigned stocks

cards.front: When does a firm act as a broker (agent)?
cards.back: When it executes trades on behalf of customers and earns a commission

cards.front: When does a firm act as a dealer (principal)?
cards.back: When it trades from its own inventory and earns a markup or markdown

cards.front: What is a markup?
cards.back: The dealer's profit when selling to a customer (added to the ask price)

cards.front: What is a markdown?
cards.back: The dealer's profit when buying from a customer (subtracted from the bid price)

cards.front: What is the 5% markup policy?
cards.back: A FINRA guideline (not rule) that markups/commissions should generally not exceed 5%

cards.front: Can a firm charge both a commission AND a markup on the same trade?
cards.back: NO - this is called a hidden profit and is prohibited

cards.front: What is the bid-ask spread?
cards.back: The difference between the highest price a buyer will pay (bid) and lowest price a seller will accept (ask)

cards.front: What is a clearing firm?
cards.back: A broker-dealer that clears and settles trades for itself and other firms

cards.front: What does the Securities Act of 1933 regulate?
cards.back: The PRIMARY market - requires registration and disclosure for new securities offerings

cards.front: What does the Securities Exchange Act of 1934 regulate?
cards.back: The SECONDARY market - created the SEC and regulates exchanges, broker-dealers, and trading

cards.front: What does the Investment Company Act of 1940 regulate?
cards.back: Mutual funds, closed-end funds, and UITs (investment companies)

cards.front: What does the Investment Advisers Act of 1940 regulate?
cards.back: Investment advisers who provide advice about securities for compensation

cards.front: What is the role of the SEC?
cards.back: Federal agency that enforces securities laws, protects investors, and maintains fair markets

cards.front: What is FINRA?
cards.back: A self-regulatory organization (SRO) that oversees broker-dealers and their registered representatives

cards.front: What is the MSRB?
cards.back: Municipal Securities Rulemaking Board - regulates firms dealing in municipal securities

cards.front: What does SIPC protect?
cards.back: Customer assets if a broker-dealer fails (up to $500,000, including $250,000 cash)

cards.front: What must be filed for a Suspicious Activity Report (SAR)?
cards.back: Transactions of $5,000 or more that appear to involve money laundering or fraud

cards.front: How are funds deposited into a fixed annuity?
cards.back: Into a GENERAL ACCOUNT. Fixed annuity funds go into the insurer's general account (not a separate account, which is for variable annuities).

cards.front: A customer has $6,000 of capital gains and $10,000 of capital losses. How much loss is deductible from this year's tax return?
cards.back: $3,000. Net capital loss is $4,000 ($10,000 - $6,000). Only $3,000 of net capital losses can be deducted in a tax year. The remaining $1,000 is carried forward to the next tax year.

cards.front: A registered representative offers to repurchase a customer's shares at $18 when the market is $10-$10.50. Is this permitted?
cards.back: NO - this is PROHIBITED. FINRA Conduct Rules do not allow customer accounts to be guaranteed against loss. If the market moves up, customer wins; if it moves down, customer loses.

cards.front: What is TRUE about the FINRA 5% Mark-Up Policy?
cards.back: 5% is a GUIDE, not a rule. Mark-ups can be MORE or LESS than 5% depending on the transaction. Easy transactions = lower markup; difficult transactions = higher markup. Applies to both principal (markup) and agency (commission) transactions.

cards.front: Can a registered representative direct customers to a friend's private placement?
cards.back: ONLY with prior WRITTEN approval from employer. RRs are prohibited from 'private securities transactions' unless they: (1) provide written notice to member firm, (2) detail compensation in writing, (3) obtain express written approval from member firm.

cards.front: Which communications do NOT need principal review? Letters to clients, complaint letters, form letters to customers, or internal form letters?
cards.back: INTERNAL form letters (for internal use within a firm). Retail communications (>25 clients) need principal approval. Correspondence (โค25 clients) needs post-use review. Internal documents don't need review because the public doesn't see them.

cards.front: What must be disclosed on a U4 Form? Residence, employers, foreign bank accounts, or bankruptcies?
cards.back: NOT foreign bank accounts. U4 requires: residence for past 5 years, employers for past 10 years, and any bankruptcies/judgments/liens. No requirement to disclose bank accounts.

cards.front: What is NOT covered under the Securities Exchange Act of 1934?
cards.back: REGISTRATION OF NEW ISSUES (that's the 1933 Act). The 1934 Act covers: registration of broker-dealers, registration of exchanges, and stabilization of new issues in the secondary market.

cards.front: During variable annuity accumulation phase, what happens to interest, dividends, and capital gains?
cards.back: Automatically reinvested to buy more ACCUMULATION UNITS (not annuity units) and build up TAX DEFERRED. This tax deferral is the major advantage over direct mutual fund investment.

cards.front: How are payments from a TAX-QUALIFIED variable annuity taxed?
cards.back: 100% TAXABLE as ordinary income. Contributions were tax-deductible, so the plan has a zero cost basis. ALL distributions are taxable. (Non-qualified annuities only tax the earnings portion.)

cards.front: What does a rep NOT need to disclose when recommending a variable annuity?
cards.back: NOT 'premium reductions for enhanced riders' - enhanced riders INCREASE premium cost. Must disclose: surrender period/charge, tax penalties, mortality & expense fees, and charges for enhanced riders.

cards.front: An open-end fund has NAV of $10/share. What is the minimum purchase price?
cards.back: $10 (the NAV). Open-end funds are purchased at NAV plus any sales load. A no-load fund = just NAV. Closed-end funds trade at market price (which can differ from NAV) plus commission.

cards.front: How often must mutual funds send financial statements to shareholders?
cards.back: SEMI-ANNUALLY (twice per year). Mutual funds must send financial statements to shareholders two times per year.

cards.front: What does the municipal bond counsel NOT opine on?
cards.back: NOT FEASIBILITY (economic viability). Bond counsel opines on: validity, legality, and tax-exempt status. They examine legal/tax issues, not economic opinions.

cards.front: A bond rated BBB by S&P is what quality?
cards.back: LOWEST QUALITY INVESTMENT GRADE. Investment grade ratings: AAA (highest), AA, A, BBB (lowest investment grade). Below BBB = speculative/junk.

cards.front: What is interpositioning and is it permitted?
cards.back: PROHIBITED. Interpositioning is adding unnecessary middlemen to a transaction, which increases costs to the customer. A registered representative cannot interposition themselves between customer and market.
